defect.para: American Transportation has mailed to the affected customers the following notice. This notice is sent to you in accordance with the requirements of the National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act. American Transportation Corporation has determined that the mirror system in certain AmTran® RE and AmTran® FE school buses fails to conform to federal regulation requirements (49 CFR 571.111 9.3(a), also known as FMVSS No.111, Section 9.3(a)).

On some of the subject AmTran RE and AmTran FE buses, the lower support arm of the driver's left side rear view mirror obscures the line of sight from the left crossview mirror to the top surface of two FMVSS 111 test cylinders located at the centerline of the rear axle. The mirror system involved is with the Rosco non-breakaway left driver's mirror only. The same two cylinders that are obscured through the cross view mirror are very visible through the left driver's mirror.
The affected AmTran FE and AmTran RE model school buses were built from August 28, 2000 through March 23, 2001.

ownernote.para: The customer has been sent a recall letter asking them to complete and return the " AUTHORIZATION FOR RECALL SERVICE" card that was enclosed with their notice. When the card is returned to us with box number 8 checked, we will forward to their attention a kit and instructions to move the left driver's mirror to eliminate the obscured line of sight.

svcproc.title: SERVICE PROCEDURE
svcproc.para: The owner was told that they may make this repair or contact their dealer to perform this repair. The repair procedure involves the driver's left rear view mirror only.

RE Models: Remove the driver's mirror from the bus. Apply new sealer to the mirror mounting angles and remount the mirror to the bus by locating the lowest mounting angle to the second hole from the bottom of the original four hole mounting pattern. This will raise the mirror 3 1/8 inches from its original location. The third mounting angle from the bottom will align with the top hole of the original four-hole pattern. Using a 7/64 drill bit, drill two new holes to mount the second and forth mounting angle from the bottom, using the angles as a template. Use the same screws to remount the mirror. Use the same type of screws to plug the unused holes.

figure.caption: Relocated Mirror Mounting on RE Model

calloutgroup.callout1: 1. TWO HOLES NEED TO BE ADDED

svcproc.para: FE Models: Remove the driver's mirror from the bus. Disassemble the hardware to turn the upper arm upper mounting angle upside down and reassemble the hardware. Apply new sealer to the mirror mounting angles and remount the mirror to the bus by locating the lowest mounting angle to the second hole from the bottom of the original four hole mounting pattern. This will raise the mirror 3 1/8 inches from its original location. The third mounting angle from the bottom will align with the top hole of the original four-hole pattern. Using a 7/64 drill bit, drill one new hole to mount the second mounting angle from the bottom, using the angle as a template. Use the same screws to remount the mirror. Use the same type of screws to plug the unused holes.

figure.caption: FE Showing New Location of the 3-Point Mounting

calloutgroup.callout1: 1. FE MODEL UPPER ARM UPPER MOUNTING ANGLE MOUNTED UPSIDE DOWN PER INSTRUCTIONS

entry.para: Screw, Self Drilling ¼ x 1 ¼" SST
Remove, rework and install mirror assembly

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified from your dealer location.

The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired within 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.

To avoid having to replace an owner vehicle or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair his or her vehicle as soon as possible.
